Award.AwardTitle: Tailoring biocatalysts by combining protein and cofactor engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
#1159434
Lutz, Stefan

Enzymes can be highly effective, selective and sustainable alternatives to chemical catalysts. Nevertheless, their application is often hampered by discrepancies between the functional demands on these biocatalysts in nature versus requirements in laboratory and industrial processes. Protein engineering by rational design and laboratory evolution offers a powerful solution for tailoring enzymes to overcome these differences.

Principle investigators Stefan Lutz and Dale Edmondson of Emory University are exploring new engineering strategies for tailoring the catalytic function, substrate specificity and enantioselectivity of flavin-dependent oxidoreductases, an important category of enzymes for asymmetric reduction and oxidation chemistry in biotechnological and pharmaceutical, as well as bioremediation applications. What makes this category of enzymes particularly interesting from a standpoint of protein engineering is their functional complementarity. The protein primarily serves as a scaffold to bind and pre-orient cofactor and substrate(s) while the cofactor is responsible for the chemistry in the active site. By simultaneously remodeling the protein and cofactor, the PIs? approach to generating and assessing many variants offers a unique opportunity to explore synergistic effects that can translate into enzyme redesign and significant enhancements of the functional versatility, catalytic performance and physicochemical properties of existing biocatalysts.


The collaborative research project offers opportunity for a highly interdisciplinary training environment for graduate and undergraduate students, as well as provides a framework for outreach involving new curriculum development activities for Atlanta-area high school teachers. Working with the Center for Science Education at Emory and the Georgia Intern-Fellowship for Teachers (GIFT) program, new hands-on experiments on green chemistry and biocatalysis will be developed. The PIs will also continue to participate in Emory's summer undergraduate research experience (SURE) program, working with young scholars from across the southeastern United States, many of them representatives from minorities and underrepresented groups, on new ideas to tweak biocatalysts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of enzymes as biocatalysts is a rapidly emerging field, offering a green and sustainable way for producing high value fine chemicals and pharmaceutical products. The growth in the area has been particularly benefited from advances in molecular biology, allowing scientists and engineers to tailor natural enzymes for specific industrial applications. 

As part of our NSF-sponsored research, we have explored the application of circular permutation to improve the function of a biocatalyst named Old Yellow Enzyme 1 (OYE1) that has been isolated from brewer’s yeast. OYE1 catalyzes the highly stereoselective transhydrogenation of activated alkenes including important precursors for flavor and fragrance compounds, as well as a wide range of pharmaceutical precursors. The application of the circular permutation method offers the means to reorganize the enzyme’s protein sequence which introduces greater flexibility in various parts of its three-dimensional structure. The results of our three-year study have demonstrated that changes in protein flexibility can result in significant functional improvements of OYE1 by over an order of magnitude. Some of our OYE1 variants are currently being tested for their suitability as biocatalysts in industrial settings. Furthermore, our in-depth analysis of permutated OYE1 variants has provided a better understanding of this method’s effects on enzymes at the molecular level. Such information is invaluable for future re-design of this and other biocatalysts. 

Our efforts to improve OYE1 function by circular permutation have been accompanied by a second strategy to generate better biocatalysts. OYE1 uses a flavin cofactor to perform its catalytic function. As part of this NSF-sponsored research project, we have prepared a series of synthetic flavin cofactor analogs, tuning the reactivity of the cofactor by introducing different chemical substitutions. Subsequently, we explored the effects of these synthetic flavin cofactor analogs on the overall function of OYE1. Although the observed changes were moderate, our findings demonstrate the ability to further modulate biocatalytic activity with synthetic cofactors.

Finally, this NSF-support project has resulted in the development of a novel tool to evaluate engineered variants of natural enzymes. Molecular biology methods such as circular permutation typically require a time and labor-intensive protocol to assess individual enzyme variants. Challenged by these limitations, we have designed, implemented and validated a new protocol named RAPPER (RApid Parallel Protein EvaluatoR) that enables the functional evaluation of several hundred biocatalyst candidates in less than a day. Besides demonstrating the protocol’s effectiveness for our OYE1 project, we have successfully applied RAPPER to measure catalytic performance for a wide variety of other biocatalysts, setting the stage for more cost and time-effective ways to find biocatalysts with superior function for a particular chemical reaction.
